case_name: V. R. Subramanyam v. B. Thayappa

facts.text: V. R. Subramanyam is the owner of plot No. 29, Subedar Chattram Road in the town of Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: V. R. Subramanyam, the appellant herein is the owner of plot No. 29, Subedar Chattram Road in the town of Bangalore.

facts.text: B. Thayappa is a building contractor.

anchor.surface_text: B. Thayappa respondent is a building contractor.

facts.text: Appellant entrusted respondent with constructing a house and shops on the plot per written agreement dated October 1, 1942, modified on October 6, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant entrusted the respondent with the work of constructing a house and shops on the plot, on terms and conditions set out in a written agreement dated October 1, 1942, which was slightly modified on October 6, 1942.

facts.text: Agreement required construction of six shops abutting public road, main building at rear, out-house, garage according to site plan.

anchor.surface_text: By the agreement the respondent was to construct for the appellant on the plot six shops abutting a public road, the main building at the rear of the shops, an out-house and a garage according to a site plan.

facts.text: Remuneration rates: Rs. 4-2-0 per square foot for R.C.C. roofing, Rs. 3-2-0 for tiled construction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was to be remunerated at rates specified in the agreement for constructions with R. C. C. roofing, the rate stipulated was Rs. 4-2-0 per square foot and for tiled construction it was Rs. 3-2-0 per square foot.

facts.text: Municipality of Bangalore did not sanction the proposed plan; altered plan sanctioned deleting shops, increasing out-house area, adding puja room on ground floor, extra room on first floor, and compound wall.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality of Bangalore did not sanction the plan as proposed by the appellant. The plan was altered and it was sanctioned, subject to those alterations. By the alterations the shops were deleted from the plan, the area of the out-house was increased, and a puja room on the ground floor and an extra room on the first floor were added to the plan. A compound wall was also to be constructed.

facts.text: Respondent carried out substantial part of construction work according to plan; appellant paid Rs. 20,200 aggregate including materials.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent carried out a substantial part of the construction work according to plan and the appellant paid to him diverse sums of money and delivered building materials. The aggregate amount accordingly received by the respondent was Rs. 20,200.

facts.text: Disputes arose before completion about defective work and extra remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: But before the work could be completed disputes arose between the appellant and the respondent about the work done by the latter.

facts.text: Appellant claimed defective work entitling compensation for repairs.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that the work done was defective and that he was entitled to compensation for effecting repairs necessary to rectify the defects.

facts.text: Respondent claimed compensation for extra work not expressly in agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed compensation at certain rates set up by him for work done for the appellant for which no express provision was made in the written agreement.

facts.text: Each party claimed an oral agreement for remuneration on extra work.

anchor.surface_text: Each party set up an oral agreement about the remuneration to be paid to the respondent for the extra work which was not included in the original agreement.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit O.S. 54 of 1946-47 for Rs. 8,515-4-0 for defective work and delay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a suit in the court of the Subordinate Judge, Bangalore, against the respondent which was later transferred to the court of the Principal District Judge, Bangalore, and numbered O. S. 54 of 1946-47, for a decree for Rs. 8,515-4-0 being the amount of compensation which the appellant claimed he was entitled to receive from the respondent for defective work and for delay in completion of the construction.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit No. 55 of 1946-47 for Rs. 5,988-12-0 remuneration less Rs. 20,200 received.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a suit against the appellant which was later transferred to the Court of the Principal District Judge, Bangalore, and numbered 55 of 1946-47. By this suit, the respondent claimed a decree for Rs. 5,988-12-0 being the remuneration due to him for the work done in constructing the house less Rs. 20,200 received from the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit No. 117 of 1945-46 for Rs. 15,001-10-9 for out-house, godown, first floor room, steps, materials removed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed another suit No. 117 of 1945-46 for a decree for Rs. 15,001-10-9 with interest and notice charges being the amount due to him for the construction of the out-house, godown, first floor room and flight of steps and the value of some building materials which the respondent claimed he had left in the premises of the appellant and which the latter had wrongfully removed.

facts.text: Principal District Judge, Bangalore decreed on January 9, 1948: appellant Rs. 3,000 in OS 54; respondent Rs. 2,989-6-0 in 55, Rs. 13,329-10-9 in 117.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 21. 1951, of the Mysore High Court in Regular Appeals Nos. 3,24,13 and 25 of 1948. 49, arising out of the judgment and decree dated January 9, 1948, of the Principal District Judge, Bangalore, in Original Suits Nos. 55 of 1946-47 and 117 of 1945-46 respectively.

facts.text: Mysore High Court on September 21, 1951 reversed decree in OS 54 dismissing appellant's claim; set aside decrees in 55 and 117, remanded for commissioner to assess extra work.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 21. 1951, of the Mysore High Court...

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals Nos. 321 and 322 of 1956 by special leave under Art. 136 against High Court directions in suits 55 and 117.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 321 and 322 of 1956. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 21. 1951, of the Mysore High Court...

facts.text: Dispute relates to construction of out-house, garage, puja room, first floor room, staircase, compound wall.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute between the parties related to the construction of the out-house, garage, puja room, the room on the first floor, the stair case leading to the upper floor room and the compound wall.

facts.text: District Judge awarded respondent Rs. 4-2-0 per sq ft for most extras except compound wall at Rs. 5 per running foot.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of these constructions except for the compound wall the District Judge awarded compensation to the respondents at the rate of Rs. 4-2-0 per square foot and in respect of the compound wall he awarded compensation at the rate of Rs. 5 per running foot, and certain additional charges.

facts.text: High Court held respondent entitled to prevailing market rates for constructions not covered by agreements.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the respondent was entitled to receive compensation at the prevailing market rate for constructions which were not covered by the agreements dated October 1, 1942 and October 6, 1942.

facts.text: High Court negatived respondent's plea of oral agreement for extra rates.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived the plea of the respondent that the appellant had agreed to pay him at extra rates for deviations and additions not specifically contained in the original agreement.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no oral agreement proved but respondent entitled to compensation quantum meruit under s.70 Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: If a party to a contract has rendered service to the other not intending to do so gratuitously and the other person has obtained some benefit, the former is entitled to compensation for the value of the services rendered by him Evidently, the respondent made additional constructions to the building and they were not done gratuitously.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals with costs on February 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.- ... The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.
with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution and he challenges the directions given in the order of remand.

issues.text: Whether the respondent's suit should have been dismissed upon failure to prove the oral agreement, without awarding compensation on quantum meruit which was not claimed, and whether the respondent must succeed or fail solely on the pleaded case

anchor.surface_text: the suit should have been dismissed, and they should not have awarded compensation quantum meruit which was not claimed. it was urged that the respondent must succeed or fail on the case pleaded by him, and not on a cause of action not pleaded. In our view, there is nosubstance in this contention. As we have already observed, in respect

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in directing that compensation for additional work be assessed in accordance with the rates mentioned in Ex. II

anchor.surface_text: It was then urged that the High Court was in error in directing assessment of compensation for the additional work in accordance with the rates mentioned in Ex. II. The plaintiffs witness T. S. Narayana Rao had admitted that the rates in Ex. II were the current market rates for building construction work similar to the appellants building.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was entitled to claim loss due to defective work by way of equitable set off against the respondent's claims in the companion suits

anchor.surface_text: Finally it was urged that the appellant was entitled to claim the loss suffered by him on account of defective work by way of an equitable set off in the claim made by the respondent in suits Nos. 55 of 1946-47 and 117 of 1945-46. But the appellant made a claim in a substantive suit for compensation for loss suffered by him because of the alleged defective work done by the respondent.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court set aside and directed market rates for uncovered items; Supreme Court upholds remand directions

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contention that the respondent's suit should be dismissed for failure to prove the oral agreement and that quantum meruit compensation cannot be awarded as not pleaded; the respondent is entitled to compensation under s.70 of the Contract Act for non-gratuitous additional work from which the appellant obtained benefit, without substantial departure from the pleaded claim.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, there is nosubstance in this contention. As we have already observed, in respect of the additional work done by the respondent, both the parties set up conflicting oral agreements. These were not accepted by the High Court. If a party to a contract has rendered service to the other not intending to do so gratuitously and the other person has obtained some benefit, the former is entitled to compensation for the value of the services rendered by him. Evidently, the respondent made additional constructions to the building and they were not done gratuitously.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conflicting oral agreements rejected; s.70 applies as services non-gratuitous and benefit obtained; award under statute aligns with claim for market rates.

holdings.text: The High Court did not err in directing assessment of compensation for additional work using rates in Ex. II, as they were admitted current market rates by appellant's witness and direction restricts enquiry scope without serious error warranting interference.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs witness T. S. Narayana Rao had admitted that the rates in Ex. II were the current market rates for building construction work similar to the appellants building. In the view of the High Court, the rates set out in that bill were not excessive. If with a view to restrict the scope of the enquiry, the learned judges of the High Court gave a direction to the Commissioner for assessing compensation on the basis of rates which were approved by the plaintiffs witness, it cannot be said that any serious error was committed in incorporating that direction which would justify our interference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witness admission confirms rates as market; High Court direction practical and non-excessive; no basis for Supreme Court interference.

holdings.text: Appellant not entitled to equitable set off for loss from defective work against respondent's claims, as substantive suit dismissed by High Court without appeal and no set off plea raised in written statements of companion suits.

anchor.surface_text: But the appellant made a claim in a substantive suit for compensation for loss suffered by him because of the alleged defective work done by the respondent. That suit was dismissed by the High Court and it is not open to the appellant thereafter to seek to reagitate the same question in the companion suits when no appeal has been preferred against the decree in suit No. 54 of 1946-47.- and no plea of equitable set off has been raised in the written statements in the companion suits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate suit final without appeal; no pleading of set off in relevant suits bars reagitation.
